Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: Tonight is the only evening my boyfriend and I have together before he leaves for a week-long business trip. He’s been looking forward to this—dinner, a movie, just us. I promised I’d be done with work on time. But as I stare at my computer, headset still on, I see the sales numbers blinking on my screen. I’m three sales short of my weekly target, and there’s only an hour left in my shift. Management has been clear: hit your numbers or risk losing your bonus. My phone buzzes with a text from him: “Can’t wait to see you. Should I start the movie?” My heart twists. I want to be the girlfriend who keeps her promises, who’s present and loving. But I also need to be the telemarketer who delivers, who doesn’t let the team down. The clock ticks louder, and I feel pulled in two directions, each expectation weighing on me, demanding I choose.
